summary: On July 23, 2018, the U.S. District Court for the District of Delaware entered jurisdiction over Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada's (Sun Life), a subsidiary of Sun Life Financial, Inc., for failing to pay over a tax refund that Plaintiff contends belongs to it under the stock purchase agreement.  According to the SEC's complaint, Sun Life agreed to convey all of its issued and outstanding shares of BarbCo3 stock to G1001, a Canadian company, in exchange for a $10,073,433 tax refund paid to a non-party subsidiary.  The complaint alleges that the Court of Chancery did not have jurisdiction over this matter because it did not consider the merits of the complaint.  Instead, the complaint alleges, the court simply held that the parties had no jurisdiction over any action touching, however tangentially, any contract involving an LLC.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, G1001 consented to the entry of a final judgment that permanently enjoins the Court from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and orders G1001 to pay disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and a civil penalty equal to the amount of the civil penalty.  G1001 also agreed to be barred from serving as an officer or director of a public company for five years.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of New York today announced criminal charges against G1001.   The SEC's Office of Investor Education and Advocacy has issued anÂ Investor AlertÂ to encourage investors to check the background of anyone selling or offering them an investment using the free and simple search tool on Investor.gov. Â The SEC's Complaint, filed in federal district court in Delaware, charges Sun Life with violating Section 18-111 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and seeks permanent injunctions, civil penalties, and penny stock bars against Sun Life, Group One Thousand One, LLC, and G1001 with violating Sections 5(a), 5(c), and 5(d) ofÂ the Securities Act.Â Sun Life has agreed to settle the matter by consenting to a judgment that imposes permanent injunctive relief, including a permanent officer-and-director bar, and to a penny stock bar.  On August 2, 2016, the SEC filed a complaint in the Delaware District Court alleging that Sun Life violated the federal securities laws by not paying over $10 million in pre-closing tax refunds to a third party, despite repeated requests from G1001 that the court had jurisdiction over all of the
